description:
Bordetella bronchiseptica is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and motile bacterium that belongs to the genus Bordetella. It is a common respiratory pathogen that can infect a wide range of mammalian hosts, including humans, dogs, cats, pigs, and various other animals.

Bordetella bronchiseptica is characterized by its ability to adhere to the ciliated epithelial cells of the respiratory tract, where it can cause inflammation and damage. This bacterium is known to produce various virulence factors, such as adhesins, toxins, and immunomodulatory proteins, which contribute to its pathogenicity.

The bacterium is typically associated with respiratory infections, such as kennel cough in dogs, atrophic rhinitis in pigs, and occasional respiratory illnesses in humans, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Infections can range in severity from asymptomatic carriage to severe pneumonia, depending on the host's immune status and other underlying factors.

Bordetella bronchiseptica is considered an opportunistic pathogen, and its prevalence and clinical significance may vary depending on the specific host and environmental conditions. Accurate identification and appropriate antimicrobial treatment are essential for managing infections caused by this bacterium.
